meta.title: Occupational Health Service Management — Wisdom → Super-Concepts → Systems → Governance → Operations → Improvement → Cases
meta.subtitle: Expanded lattice with dense, meaningful interconnections: ethics/law/trust constrain information flows; systems dynamics shape service reliability; governance structures programmes; operations create outputs; quality closes feedback loops back to strategy.
meta.searchPlaceholder: COSHH, WELs, AREC, hierarchy of control, exposure monitoring, health surveillance, audiometry, HAVS, WBGT/PHS, lighting/glare, SDS/CLP, consent, confidentiality, RIDDOR, HASAWA, SEQOHS, ISO 45001, PDCA, KPIs, outsourcing, drift, interfaces…
meta.userContextPlaceholder: e.g., multi-site organisation; outsourced OH; noise+solvents; backlog; confidentiality complaints; need governance + KPIs + integration with H&S…
meta.promptTemplate:
You are an expert occupational health service director with occupational hygiene literacy and systems-thinking capability.

Write a realistic narrative case-study showing how upstream constraints (ethics, law, systems dynamics, incentives) shape downstream OH service performance.
Use the selected concepts to explain what to do, why it works, and how to govern it.

User context (if provided):
{{USER_CONTEXT}}

Selected concepts:
{{SELECTED_TITLES}}

Details:
{{SELECTED_DETAILS}}

Trace paths:
{{TRACE_SUMMARY}}

Deliver:
- Scenario description (industry, hazards, stakeholders, constraints)
- Diagnosis of failure modes (interfaces, drift, incentives, work-as-done)
- OH operating model + programme portfolio (chemicals/noise/vibration/thermal/lighting + case management)
- Legal + ethical compliance plan (consent/confidentiality, reporting, COSHH/RIDDOR duties)
- Operational playbook (triage, consultation, report, escalation)
- Measurement plan: leading + lagging indicators + learning loops
- 2 safe-to-fail experiments with backfire checks

levels.title: Professional wisdom
levels.hint: Judgement-in-context: trust, ethics, proportion, learning and dignity under real organisational pressure.

levels.title: Super-concepts
levels.hint: Shaping ideas: risk, uncertainty, stakeholder legitimacy, incentives, communication, and the worker–employer tension.

levels.title: Systems concepts
levels.hint: How services behave: feedback, drift, interfaces, flow, boundaries, incentives, work-as-done vs work-as-imagined.

levels.title: Service governance & programme architecture
levels.hint: Commissioning, governance, legal compliance, programme portfolio, and integration with H&S.

levels.title: Operational delivery mechanisms
levels.hint: Consultations, surveillance, monitoring, control verification, reporting, training, records, incident response.

levels.title: Quality, performance & improvement
levels.hint: Standards, audit, KPIs, competence assurance, continuous improvement, organisational learning.

levels.title: Cases, challenges & pathologies
levels.hint: Concrete scenarios and common failure modes for tracing back to roots.

nodes.label: Listening (serious attention)
nodes.summary: Listen beyond dashboards: worker stories, near-miss narratives, complaint themes, and "unease" signals.
nodes.bodyHtml: Wise OH management treats lived experience as system data. Listening surfaces friction, adaptations, and weak signals that metrics miss—especially around confidentiality, trust, and control usability.

nodes.label: Grace (non-blame + dignity)
nodes.summary: Protect dignity; reduce shame; keep reporting safe so weak signals keep flowing.
nodes.bodyHtml: OH programmes fail when people fear punishment or humiliation. Non-blame practice preserves trust and makes early reporting possible (symptoms, near misses, control failures).

nodes.label: Proportion & timing
nodes.summary: Right-sized action; don’t flood the system with rules; match interventions to capacity and risk.
nodes.bodyHtml: OH management is full of trade-offs (surveillance intensity, sampling depth, clinic capacity). Proportionate decisions are ethically and legally defensible and prevent compliance theatre.

nodes.label: Ethics & fairness as design constraints
nodes.summary: Consent, confidentiality, justice and autonomy are structural constraints that stabilise trust and legitimacy.
nodes.bodyHtml: Ethical practice is not a “soft extra”. It determines whether employees engage with OH, accept surveillance, and trust advice—directly affecting system performance.

nodes.label: Holism (whole-system view)
nodes.summary: Don’t optimise one metric at the expense of health; outcomes emerge from interactions across the system.
nodes.bodyHtml: OH success depends on procurement, engineering, rostering, supervision, culture, and incentives—not only clinics and reports.

nodes.label: Safe-to-fail experiments
nodes.summary: Test → learn → adapt in short cycles; prevent backfire in complex problems.
nodes.bodyHtml: Many OH interventions backfire when rolled out as one big change. Safe-to-fail pilots use leading indicators and explicit backfire checks before scaling.

nodes.label: Reflection & sensemaking
nodes.summary: Turn information into understanding; check assumptions; avoid blaming individuals for system problems.
nodes.bodyHtml: Reflection converts exposure data, surveillance outcomes, complaints, and audit findings into improvements in controls, interfaces, and governance.

nodes.label: Risk-based prioritisation
nodes.summary: Allocate OH attention where harm is most likely/severe, using defensible criteria (hazard, exposure, vulnerability, uncertainty).
nodes.bodyHtml: OH management prioritises programmes and casework based on risk—not volume or loudest stakeholder.

nodes.label: Two-master ethics (worker–employer tension)
nodes.summary: Balance individual welfare, public/colleague safety, organisational needs and fairness.
nodes.bodyHtml: OH managers must design processes that keep independence credible: consent, confidentiality, relevance in reports, appeal pathways.

nodes.label: Law, dutyholders & accountability
nodes.summary: Translate statutory/common-law duties and enforcement expectations into operational governance.
nodes.bodyHtml: Core themes: ‘reasonably practicable’, COSHH duties, RIDDOR reporting, consultation duties, and data protection.

nodes.label: Consent & confidentiality governance
nodes.summary: Consistent rules for consent, information sharing, report access, and exceptional disclosures.
nodes.bodyHtml: Operationalise consent: what will be shared, with whom, why, and rights—while managing lawful exceptions and expectations.

nodes.label: Stakeholder communication & risk perception
nodes.summary: Turn technical risk into actionable, comprehensible messages for workers, managers, unions and regulators.
nodes.bodyHtml: Miscommunication can destroy trust even when technical work is sound. OH management needs templates and escalation pathways.

nodes.label: Uncertainty & model limits
nodes.summary: Prognosis and exposure–effect relationships can be uncertain; false certainty creates brittleness and distrust.
nodes.bodyHtml: Express uncertainty honestly (ranges, conditions). Build policies tolerant to variation and revise via feedback.

nodes.label: Information → Knowledge → Wisdom ladder
nodes.summary: More data ≠ better decisions; interpretation and judgement matter.
nodes.bodyHtml: OH generates lots of data (surveillance, exposure measurements, absence metrics). The management challenge is converting it into action without ethical drift.

nodes.label: Multidisciplinary teaming
nodes.summary: Coordinate clinicians, hygienists, H&S, engineering, HR and leadership as one risk-control system.
nodes.bodyHtml: Noise/vibration/heat/chemicals/lighting require shared ownership. OH managers align roles, escalation rules and shared KPIs.

nodes.label: Work-as-imagined vs work-as-done
nodes.summary: Policies are simplified models; real work adapts under constraint. The gap explains many control failures.
nodes.bodyHtml: LEV ‘passes’ but exposure spikes on busy days; PPE is specified but not wearable at pace; surveillance exists but follow-up fails.

nodes.label: Feedback loops
nodes.summary: Measure → learn → adapt; weak signals become actionable when captured and acted on.
nodes.bodyHtml: Design feedback loops from surveillance, monitoring, incidents and complaints into engineering controls, training and policies.

nodes.label: Entropy / drift
nodes.summary: Controls and processes degrade unless actively maintained; drift silently increases risk.
nodes.bodyHtml: Examples: expired calibration, outdated templates, informal workarounds, delayed maintenance, role ambiguity, surveillance backlogs.

nodes.label: Interfaces & handoffs
nodes.summary: Where failure clusters: referral forms, portals, report delivery, lab results, surveillance clinics, contractor chains.
nodes.bodyHtml: Many OH failures are interface failures: wrong recipient, missing consent, unclear questions, lost follow-up.

nodes.label: System boundaries (who is covered)
nodes.summary: Boundary choices decide who is included in care/accountability (employees vs contractors, sites, remote workers, supply chain).
nodes.bodyHtml: OH managers must explicitly decide coverage boundaries and ensure consistent protections and reporting across them.

nodes.label: Flow (time, attention, clinic capacity, data)
nodes.summary: Bottlenecks create pressure; pressure drives unsafe adaptations and degraded quality.
nodes.bodyHtml: Backlogs, rushed assessments, delayed controls and missing follow-up are flow problems.

nodes.label: Power & incentives
nodes.summary: Contracts, KPIs and reputational pressures reshape behaviour and can create perverse outcomes (under-reporting, compliance theatre).
nodes.bodyHtml: Measure what matters (controls, follow-up, outcomes) not just speed/volume; avoid punishment signals that suppress reporting.

nodes.label: Problem types: simple / complicated / complex
nodes.summary: Intervention choice should match problem type: checklist fixes vs engineered solutions vs adaptive learning cycles.
nodes.bodyHtml: Noise mapping is complicated; culture and trust repair is complex.

nodes.label: Commissioning, scope & operating model
nodes.summary: Define what OH provides, referral pathways, turnaround times, surveillance programmes, and integration responsibilities.
nodes.bodyHtml: Clear scope prevents dysfunctional demand and makes performance measurable and defensible.

nodes.label: Clinical governance
nodes.summary: Policies, supervision, competence, audit, safe practice, and escalation across clinicians and the wider OH team.
nodes.bodyHtml: Includes consent scripts, record standards, report templates, and handling disputes/complaints.

nodes.label: Information governance (records, access, security, retention)
nodes.summary: Operational controls for confidentiality and data protection: access control, secure delivery, retention schedules, incident response.
nodes.bodyHtml: Information governance is where ethics and law become daily operational practice.

nodes.label: Legal compliance backbone (HASAWA/COSHH/RIDDOR/consultation)
nodes.summary: Ensure statutory duties are translated into processes, evidence and accountability.
nodes.bodyHtml: Risk assessment, prevention/control, maintenance, monitoring/surveillance, incident planning, training and reporting.

nodes.label: Integration with H&S risk systems
nodes.summary: Connect OH outputs to risk registers, engineering controls, management review and consultation structures.
nodes.bodyHtml: OH must not be an isolated clinic. Surveillance and exposure findings should drive control improvements and policy changes.

nodes.label: Programme portfolio management
nodes.summary: Run coherent hazard programmes (chemicals, noise, vibration, thermal, lighting) plus case management and health promotion.
nodes.bodyHtml: Each programme needs an owner, monitoring plan, surveillance criteria, training plan, documentation, and review cadence.

nodes.label: Anticipate–Recognise–Evaluate–Control (AREC)
nodes.summary: Hygiene management cycle used to structure hazard programmes and change management.
nodes.bodyHtml: AREC connects change to exposure evaluation and control verification. Backbone of prevention-first OH management.

nodes.label: Risk assessment → risk management
nodes.summary: Risk assessment characterises risk; risk management ensures controls are implemented, maintained, communicated and reviewed.
nodes.bodyHtml: OH managers ensure assessment outputs turn into real controls and sustained outcomes.

nodes.label: Hierarchy of control
nodes.summary: Prefer elimination/substitution/engineering, then administrative controls, then PPE.
nodes.bodyHtml: OH management must avoid PPE-only responses and ensure engineering and procurement are engaged.

nodes.label: Exposure monitoring & survey strategy
nodes.summary: Plan initial/basic/detailed surveys, personal vs static sampling, and resurvey triggers.
nodes.bodyHtml: Monitoring should drive control decisions and verify effectiveness—not as a ritual.

nodes.label: Health surveillance strategy (targeted, actionable)
nodes.summary: Deploy surveillance where disease is plausible, detectable, and results trigger action.
nodes.bodyHtml: Surveillance is justified only when it can prevent harm via early detection and response.

nodes.label: Toxicology foundations (dose, route, ADME, target organs)
nodes.summary: Use toxicology to interpret hazards, limits, combined exposures, and health effects for decision-making.
nodes.bodyHtml: Supports justified monitoring, surveillance, and prioritisation for hazardous substances.

nodes.label: Hazard information systems (SDS/labels/CLP-GHS)
nodes.summary: Use labels/SDS/classification to understand hazard types; treat SDS as input, not a risk assessment.
nodes.bodyHtml: Management ensures competent interpretation and integration into exposure scenarios and controls.

nodes.label: COSHH / hazardous substances programme delivery
nodes.summary: Assess risks; prevent/control exposure; maintain controls; monitor exposure where needed; surveillance where required; train and plan for incidents.
nodes.bodyHtml: Includes inventories, exposure scenarios, control banding, sampling plans, LEV testing/maintenance, PPE governance, incident readiness.

nodes.label: Noise programme (hearing conservation)
nodes.summary: Noise surveys, engineering controls, hearing protection governance, training, audiometry, and feedback to controls.
nodes.bodyHtml: Requires senior commitment, competent measurement, and a closed loop from surveillance to control improvement.

nodes.label: Vibration programme (HAV/WBV)
nodes.summary: Identify exposures, prioritise tool/process controls, train workers, and provide monitoring and response pathways for symptoms/findings.
nodes.bodyHtml: Controls include tool procurement/maintenance, exposure estimation, supervision, and rapid action on early symptoms.

nodes.label: Thermal stress management (heat/cold)
nodes.summary: Assess exposures, implement controls (work-rest, hydration, engineering), and protect vulnerable workers with clear triggers.
nodes.bodyHtml: Plans need thresholds, supervision routines, and stop/go rules under extremes.

nodes.label: Lighting & visual environment management
nodes.summary: Manage illuminance, glare, contrast, flicker and task needs; integrate with task design and DSE.
nodes.bodyHtml: Often neglected; poor lighting contributes to errors, discomfort, fatigue and complaints.

nodes.label: Consultation standards & triage
nodes.summary: Right case to right clinician at right time; role clarity; informed consent; documentation and escalation.
nodes.bodyHtml: Standards reduce complaints and ethical drift; ensure consistency across providers and sites.

nodes.label: Teleconsultation governance (phone/video)
nodes.summary: Identity verification, adapted consent, limitations management, equity/IT barriers, and safe documentation.
nodes.bodyHtml: Operationalise safe teleconsultation with checklists and boundaries.

nodes.label: Report writing (decision-ready, relevant, minimal disclosure)
nodes.summary: Answer the question; focus on function, adjustments and prognosis ranges; protect confidentiality; document consent.
nodes.bodyHtml: Reports are the tangible output of OH. Governance must prevent pressure for unnecessary diagnoses and ensure secure delivery.

nodes.label: Fitness for work & adjustments
nodes.summary: Assess capacity, restrictions, accommodations, redeployment, and safe return-to-work pathways while balancing fairness and safety.
nodes.bodyHtml: Links clinical judgement to work design and management decisions within ethical/legal constraints.

nodes.label: Training, information & health promotion
nodes.summary: Make hazards and controls understandable; support behaviour change; increase informed participation in surveillance and controls.
nodes.bodyHtml: Training supports control sustainability and builds trust by explaining what OH does and why.

nodes.label: Incidents, escalation & emergency planning
nodes.summary: Protocols for acute exposures, heat illness events, data breaches, and serious risk disclosures; connect to organisational incident systems.
nodes.bodyHtml: Requires clear thresholds, communications plans, and documentation expectations.

nodes.label: Records management (secure, auditable, useful)
nodes.summary: Secure, consistent records for consultations, surveillance, exposure monitoring and follow-up; define access and retention.
nodes.bodyHtml: Records are the evidence layer for ethics, law, quality, and learning.

nodes.label: Complaints handling & learning
nodes.summary: Timely acknowledgement, fair investigation, honest explanation, and changes that prevent recurrence.
nodes.bodyHtml: Complaints are weak signals. Good handling increases legitimacy and improves service design.

nodes.label: SEQOHS (OH service quality standard)
nodes.summary: Governance domains: business probity, information governance, people/competence, facilities/equipment, purchaser & worker relationships.
nodes.bodyHtml: Use SEQOHS domains as an OH management checklist for outsourced or in-house services.

nodes.label: ISO 45001 / OHSMS integration
nodes.summary: Framework for managing OH&S responsibilities with continual improvement and leadership accountability.
nodes.bodyHtml: Align OH programmes with risk registers, consultation, management review, and continual improvement processes.

nodes.label: PDCA / HSG65-style management cycle
nodes.summary: Plan–Do–Check–Act: policy, organisation, planning, implementing, monitoring, audit & review.
nodes.bodyHtml: Applies to OH services: plan programmes, deliver, check effectiveness, and act on learning.

nodes.label: KPIs & indicators (leading + lagging)
nodes.summary: Measure programme maturity and outcomes, not just activity: controls implemented, coverage, follow-up timeliness, trends.
nodes.bodyHtml: Combine quantitative metrics with narrative intelligence (listening loops). Use metrics for learning, not punishment.

nodes.label: Audit, assurance & governance review
nodes.summary: Test whether practice matches standards and whether programmes work under real conditions (including peak load).
nodes.bodyHtml: Audit should detect drift, interface failure, and WAI/WAD gaps—not just paperwork completeness.

nodes.label: Competence & workforce planning
nodes.summary: Right competency mix, supervision, CPD and safe delegation—especially across outsourcing chains.
nodes.bodyHtml: Competence is a reliability control; align demand (flow) with capacity and safe practice.

nodes.label: Learning loops & continuous improvement
nodes.summary: Convert surveillance findings, exposure data, incidents and complaints into redesigned controls, training and governance.
nodes.bodyHtml: Institutional memory is maintained by structured review cadence and disciplined change control.

nodes.label: Challenge: Outsourcing & accountability drift
nodes.summary: Supply chains multiply interfaces; accountability and QA must be explicit or learning collapses.
nodes.bodyHtml: Without strong commissioning, supervision and audit, outsourced OH can optimise for speed/volume rather than quality, ethics and outcomes.

nodes.label: Pathology: Under-reporting & weak-signal collapse
nodes.summary: When reporting is punished or ignored, signals vanish and risk accumulates silently.
nodes.bodyHtml: Affects symptoms, near misses, surveillance participation, and incident reporting—destroying self-regulation.

nodes.label: Pathology: Normalisation of deviance
nodes.summary: Workarounds become ‘normal’ under pressure; controls appear compliant while real risk increases.
nodes.bodyHtml: Common in LEV use, PPE shortcuts, missed breaks in heat, and rushed surveillance follow-up.

nodes.label: Case: LEV passes tests but exposures spike on busy days
nodes.summary: WAI/WAD mismatch under throughput pressure; needs friction audit, flow redesign, and verification under load.
nodes.bodyHtml: Investigate staging, peak-load practices, maintenance, supervision, and incentives. Fix the system, not the worker.

nodes.label: Case: Hearing conservation programme stagnates
nodes.summary: Audiometry shows shifts but controls don’t improve; feedback loop is broken between surveillance and engineering.
nodes.bodyHtml: Strengthen governance: assign owners, action thresholds, engineering prioritisation, and worker engagement.

nodes.label: Case: Heat stress escalation during extreme temperatures
nodes.summary: Triggers and work-rest controls fail; needs thresholds, supervision routines, and protection of vulnerable workers.
nodes.bodyHtml: Use practical escalation, hydration and rest governance, plus monitoring of early symptoms and near misses.

nodes.label: Case: ‘We pay so we own the report’ dispute
nodes.summary: Manager demands diagnosis; worker fears disclosure. Requires consent governance and decision-ready functional reporting.
nodes.bodyHtml: Reinforce minimal necessary disclosure, informed consent, and clear explanation of OH role and boundaries.

nodes.label: Case: Report sent to the wrong person (data breach)
nodes.summary: Interface failure in secure delivery; needs incident response, root cause analysis, and stronger information governance.
nodes.bodyHtml: Fix verification steps, secure channels, access control, and staff training; apply learning loop and audit re-check.

nodes.label: Case: Audit scores rose but dermatitis increased
nodes.summary: Paper compliance hides real exposure; investigate glove availability, friction, onboarding gaps, pressure and substitutions.
nodes.bodyHtml: Use listening and WAI/WAD analysis; redesign controls and verify under real working conditions.

Outsourcing chains amplify misaligned incentives and accountability gaps.

Governance relies on competence, supervision, CPD and safe delegation.

Hazard information is an input to risk assessment but must be contextualised to real tasks and exposures.

Fitness decisions rely on structured assessment of function and work demands.
Consultations must be documented to evidence consent, reasoning, and advice.
